item.description:
Join the New Haven Shambhala Center and Michael Kern, a senior student and a school psychologist, for a short talk entitled Cultivating Patience. This is a topic related to both meditation and daily life discussed from a Shambhala Buddhist perspective. The talk is preceded by a short sitting meditation and followed by Q & A. Afterward, a short reception with light refreshments & tea will take place in the Center's lounge area.

An international community of urban meditation and rural retreat centers, Shambhala invites people to explore diverse topics and discover their inherent sanity, gentleness and humor. The New Haven Center offers practice and study in the lineage of Shambhala Buddhism, a unique practice in the world of Western Buddhism.

A free will donation for this evening's talk is requested but not required. The New Haven Shambhala Meditation Center was established in 1975 as a not-for-profit center that promotes contemplative practice and the aspiration to realize a more wakeful, enlightened society.

See these articles for more information...

Meditate on This, Daily Nutmeg, 2013
http://dailynutmeg.com/2013/01/08/shambhala-meditation-center-new-haven-meditate-on-this/

The Pursuit of Calm, New Haven Register, 2008 http://www.nhregister.com/articles/2008/10/12/life/doc48f1d0f4b2f80733361218.txt

 

New Haven Shambhala Center Meditation Room

 

"According to the legends, [there] was a place of peace and prosperity, governed by wise and compassionate rulers. The citizens of were equally kind and learned, so that, in general, the kingdom was a model society. This place was called Shambhala." (pg 25) "The basic message of the Shambhala teachings is that the best of human life can be realized under ordinary circumstances. That is the basic wisdom of Shambhala: that in this world, as it is, we can find a good and meaningful human life that will also serve others."

~ from the writings and teachings
of the Venerable Chogyam Trungpa Rinpoche
